work.p: Phrases in this manuscript are similar to phrases that appeared in the poem that would later be titled "A Song for Occupations." See, for instance: "It is for you whoever you are . . . . it is no farther from you than your hearing and sight are from you, / It is hinted by nearest and commonest and readiest . . . . it is not them, though it is endlessly provoked by them" (1855, p. 59).

Phrases in this manuscript are also similar to phrases that appeared in the poem that would later be titled "Song of Myself." See, for instance: "I take my place among you as much as among any," (1855, p. 48); "Nor do I understand who there can be more wonderful than myself" (1855, p. 54); "What is commonest and cheapest and nearest and easiest is Me" (1855, p. 21).

This manuscript also bears some resemblance to the following lines in "Salut au Monde!," first published in 1856 as "Poem of Salutation": "Stretched in due time within me the midnight sun just rises above the horizon, and sinks again; / Within me zones, seas, cataracts, plains, volca- noes, groups, / Oceanica, Australasia, Polynesia, and the great West Indian islands" (1856, p. 104).

a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Edward Grier writes of this manuscript that "[t]he sentiments and the handwriting are those of 1855 or earlier" (Notebooks and Unpublished Prose Manuscripts [New York: New York University Press, 1984], 1:186). Some of the language is similar to wording in the 1855 and 1856 poems that would be titled "Song of Myself," "A Song for Occupations," and "Salut au Monde!" At some point, this manuscript formed part of Whitman's cultural geography scrapbook.

body.p: The most perfect wonders of the earth are not I rare and distant but present with every person,—you as much as any!—
tr down Man! Woman! Youth! wherever you are, in the Northern, Southern, Eastern, or Western States—in KanadaCanada—by the sea-coast, or far inland—the

Th What is more amazing than the day sun-rise, the day, the floods of light enveloping the fields, t waters, grass, trees, persons?—What is more beautiful than the night, the full moon, and the stars?—The prairies, the lakes, t rivers, forests,—all are

Not distant caverns, volcanoes, cataracts, curious islands, birds, foreign cities, architecture, costumes, markets, ceremonies, shows, are any more wonderful than ‸ what is common to you, near you now, and continually with you.—
